_prev_prog_3.CH_OtherChanges: INCREASED CHEMICAL/ VEHICLE SEGREGATION BARRICADES.  INCREASED COMPONENT LABELING.  INCREASED UNAUTHORIZED ACCESS LIMITATION SAFEGUARDS.
_prev_prog_3.EquipmentTested: TANK PLACEMENT, VEHICULAR BARRICADES, REGULATOR/ VACUUM OPERATED SHUT OFF VALVE, VACUUM LINE, WATER PUMP, CHLORINATED WATER LINE, BUFFER/ REACTION TANKS, CHLORINATED BUFFERED WATER LINES.
_prev_prog_3.Description: THIS PROCESS CONSISTS OF CHLORINE, LIQUIFIED, UNDER PRESSURE, DRAWN BY VACUUM  TO AN EDUCTOR, WHERE IT IS INJECTED INTO WATER AND PUMPED INTO COVERED TANKS CONTAINING BUFFER, FROM WHICH IT FLOWS INTO COVERED WASH TANK/ FLUMES TO ACT AS A BACTERICIDE IN WATER USED TO WASH POTATOES..  AUTOMATIC VACUUM OPERATED SHUT OFF VALVES , AS WELL AS REGULATORS CONTROL THE FLOW  FROM TANK(S) STORED IN A  VEHICLE BARRICADED, MARKED,  FENCED AREA TO THE WATER INJECTION POINT.  WRITTEN OPERATING PROCEDURES  ARE MAINTAINED FOR ALL ASPECTS OF THE PROCESS, INCLUDING STORAGE , TRANSPORTATION , TANK HOOK- UP, START-UP, OPERATION, EMERGENCY OPERATION, SHUT-DOWN, EMERGENCY SHUT DOWN, START-UP AFTER TURNAROUND,AND EMERGENCY EVACUATION / ACTION PLANS.  ALL OPERATORS OF THE WATER CHLORINATION SYSTEM ARE TRAINED IN ALL ASPECTS OF THE STORAGE, HANDLING AND PROCESS USE OF CHLORINE.  THEY ARE TRAINED IN THE DANGERS OF CHLORINE, PROCESS OVERVIEW, STORAGE,  MOVEMENT, AND OPERATIONAL PROCEDURES OF THE PROCESS, AS WELL AS PRE-START AND OPERATIONAL MECHANICAL INTEGRITY OF THE SYSTEM COMPONENTS AND OPERATIONAL PARAMETER TESTING, AS WELL AS SHUT- DOWN AND EMERGENCY SHUT- DOWN PROCEDURES.  OPERATORS ARE ALSO TRAINED IN START- UP AFTER TURNAROUND PROCEDURES, TEMPORARY OPERATIONS, AND EMERGENCY OPERATIONS, EMERGENCY AND EVACUATION PLANS. OPERATOR TRAINING AND TESTING ARE DOCUMENTED. WRITTEN OPERATING PROCEDURES ARE PROVIDED TO THE OPERATORS AND MAINTAINED IN THE WORK AREA.      INSPECTIONS     ARE PERFORMED AND DOCUMENTED ON A DAILY, WEEKLY AND YEARLY BASIS TO ASSURE SAFE OPERATIONAL STATUS OF SYSTEM COMPONENTS.       CRITICAL SAFEGUARD COMPONENTS OF THE SYSTEM  SUCH AS CHLORINE REGULATOR/ AUTOMATIC VACUUM SHUT-OFF VALVES ARE REMOVED,  INSPECTED, SERVICED, TESTED, AND RE-INSTALLED / REPLACED  AND CHECKED FOR SAFE OPERATION YEARLY.      ANY CHANGES TO THE PROCESS ARE MANAGED SO THAT ANY EMPLOYEES THAT MAY BE AFFECTED BY SUCH CHANGES AS WELL AS PROCESS OPERATORS ARE TRAINED IN THE PARTICULARS OF ANY NEW EQUIPMENT OR PROCEDURES.  ACCIDENTS/ INCIDENTS THAT DID OR COULD HAVE RESULTED IN AN ACCIDENTAL RELEASE OF CHLORINE WILL BE IMMEDIATELY ( OR NO LATER THAN 48 HOURS)  INVESTIGATED BY PERSONS KNOWLEDGABLE IN THE PROCESS CAPABLE OF DEVELOPING A REPORT TO DETERMINE THE FACTORS INVOLVED AND PROVIDE MEANS FOR THEIR CORRECTION.  PROCESS HAZARD ANALYSES HAVE AND WILL BE CONDUCTED  TO DETERMINE HAZARDS IN TRAINING, EQUIPMENT, PROCEDURES, POSSIBLE ACTS OF NATURE, DOCUMENTATION, CONTRACTOR RESPONSIBILITIES, MANAGEMENT OF CHANGE,  EMERGENCY ACTION PLANS, SAFE STORAGE AND TRANSPORTATION OF CHLORINE.  ADDITIONALLY, COMPLIANCE AUDITS WILL BE CONDUCTED AT LEAST EVERY THREE YEARS TO EVALUATE AND CERTIFY THAT PROCESS SAFETY REQUIREMENTS ARE BEING MET.  AUDIT DEFICIENCY  FINDINGS WILL PROMPTLY BE CORRECTED AND DOCUMENTED.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
GENERAL EXECUTIVE SUMMARY FOR KIRSCHENMAN
                                                    PACKING 12826 EDISON HWY. FACILITY


      1.    ACCIDENTAL RELEASE EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES:

          KIRSCHENMAN PACKING IS COMMITTED TO THE SAFE OPERATION OF ALL ASPECTS OF THIS 
       FACILITY, PROTECTING THE HEALTH AND SAFETY OF OUR EMPLOYEES, THE PUBLIC, AND
       THE ENVIRONMENT.


      2.    STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES:

      
         OUR FACILITY'S PRIMARY ACTIVITIES ARE POTATO WASHING, SORTING, PACKING, STORAGE
      AND SHIPPING.

         THIS FACILITY USES CHLORINE AS A BACTERIAL CONTROL AGENT IN POTATO WASHING 
      OPERATIONS.

         THE MAXIMUM INVENTORY OF CHLORINE AT THIS FACILITY IS 6,000 LBS.  A MAXIMUM 
       OF 4,000 MAY BE CONNECTED IN PROCESS.  AN ADDITIONAL 2,000 LBS. MAY BE STORED
       AT THE FACILITY, BUT PLACED AND STORED IN SUCH A WAY THAT IT WOULD NOT BE
       INVOLVED IN A POTENTIAL RELEASE.


      3.    ACCIDENTAL RELEASE SCENARIOS:


           WORST CASE AND ALTERNATE RELEASE SCENARIOS WERE PERFORMED  FOR CHLORINE,
       USING RMP*COMP VERSION 1.06, "COMPUTER AIDED MANAGEMENT OF EMERGENCY OPERA-
       TIONS."
   
            THE FOLLOWING PARAGRAPHS PROVIDE DETAILS OF THOSE SCENARIOS.

            THE WORST CASE SCENARIO INVOLVES THE  CATASTROPHIC RELEASE OF 2,000 LBS.
        OF CHLORINE, LIQUIFIED, UNDER PRESSURE, COMPLETELY EMPTYING A COMPLETELY FULL
        ONE TON CYLINDER OVER A PERIOD OF 10 MIN.  (A RELEASE RATE OF 200 LBS. PER  MIN.) IN
        GENERALLY FLAT TERRAIN AND GENERALLY UNOBSTRUCTED RURAL SURROUNDINGS,
        AND AN ASSUMED 77 DEGREE AIR TEMPERATURE  AT CLASS " F"  ATMOSPHERIC 
        STABILITY  AND  1.5 m/s WIND SPEED, THE MAXIMUM OF 3 MILES IS OBTAINED          
        CORRESPONDING TO A TOXIC  ENDPOINT OF 0.0087 mg/L.  NO MITIGATION MEASURES
        WERE  ASSUMED.

            THE ALTERNATIVE SCENARIO CONSIDERED AS A MORE LIKELY RELEAS

E POSSIBILITY
        HAVING OFF SITE CONSEQUENCES, INVOLVED THE RELEASE OF  CHLORINE GAS FROM
        A  CYLINDER GAS VALVE DURING INITIAL VALVE OPENING.  INCOMPLETE SEATING OF
        THE COMPRESSIBLE WASHER WAS ASSUMED TO LEAVE  AN AGGREGATE 
        ONE TENTH SQUARE INCH OPENING, THROUGH WHICH  25.2 LBS PER MIN.OF
        GAS WAS RELEASED, UNTIL PROPERLY TRAINED AND EQUIPPED EMERGENCY
        RESPONDERS SECURED THE RELEASE BY CLOSING THE VALVE, AFTER 15 MIN.  THE RELEASE
        OF 378 LBS. OF CHLORINE  AT AN ASSUMED 77 DEGREE AIR TEMPERATURE, ATMOSPHERIC
        STABILITY CLASS "D",  WIND SPEED OF 3 METERS/ SECOND, IN GENERALLY FLAT UN-
        OBSTRUCTED RURAL SURROUNDINGS, THE MAXIMUM OF .3 MILES IS OBTAINED CORRESPOND-
        ING TO A TOXIC ENDPOINT OF 0.0087 mg/L.  NO MITIGATION MEASURES WERE CONSIDERED 
        OTHER THAN THE TIMELY RESPONSE BY PROPERLY TRAINED AND EQUIPPED EMERGENCY
        RESPONDERS.

           
        4.   GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND CHEMICAL SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS


              THIS FACILITY HAS TAKEN ALL NECESSARY STEPS TO COMPLY WITH THE ACCIDENTAL 
         RELEASE PREVENTION REQUIREMENTS OF 40 CFR PART 68 OF THE EPA.

              THIS FACILITY MAINTAINS DETAILED RECORDS OF SAFETY INFORMATION DESCRIBING
         CHEMICAL HAZARDS, OPERATING PARAMETERS AND EQUIPMENT ASSOCIATED WITH THE 
         WATER CHLORINATION PROCESS.

              PROCESS HAZARD ANALYSIS:  OUR FACILITY CONDUCTS STUDIES TO IDENTIFY AND
          CONTROL HAZARDS, USING A WHAT IF / CHECKLIST (COMBINED) METHODOLOGY.  THE
          MOST RECENT PHA WAS PERFORMED ON 12-10-01.

             OPERATING PROCEDURES:  OUR FACILITY MAINTAINS WRITTEN OPERATING PROCEDURES
           FOR ALL MODES OF OPERATION, INCLUDING START-UP, START-UP AFTER TURNAROUND,
           NORMAL AND TEMPORARY OPERATIONS, NORMAL AND EMERGENCY SHUT DOWN OPERA-
           TIONS.

             TRAINING:  KIRSCHENMAN PACKING HAS A TRAINING PROGRAM TO ENSURE THAT
           EMPLO

YEE PROCESS OPERATORS ARE COMPETENT IN PROCESS OPERATING PROCEDURES.

              MECHANICAL INTEGRITY:  KIRSCHENMAN  PACKING  CARRIES OUT MAINTENANCE CHECKS
           ON PROCESS EQUIPMENT TO ENSURE PROPER OPERATION.  PROCESS EQUIPMENT  EXAMINED
           BY THE CHECKS INCLUDE CHEMICAL CYLINDERS, BUFFER TANKS, PIPING SYSTEMS,
           PUMPS, SUCTION FANS, AUTOMATIC VACUUM OPERATED VALVES, REGULATORS, CHECK
           VALVES, EDUCTORS, AND VEHICLE BARRICADES.  DEFICIENCIES IDENTIFIED ARE CORRECTED
           IN A SAFE AND TIMELY MANNER.

               MANAGEMENT OF CHANGE:  WRITTEN PROCEDURES ARE IN PLACE TO MANAGE CHANGES
           IN PROCESS, CHEMICALS, TECHNOLOGY, EQUIPMENT, AND PROCEDURES.  PROCESS
           OPERATORS, MAINTENANCE PERSONNEL, AND OTHER EMPLOYEES AFFECTED BY THESE
           CHANGES, WILL BE MADE AWARE OF CHANGES AND RE-TRAINED AS NECESSARY.

               PRE-START REVIEWS:  PRE- START UP REVIEWS OF NEW/ MODIFIED PROCESSES WILL
            BE CONDUCTED TO ENSURE THAT CONSTRUCTION, EQUIPMENT, OPERATING AND
            MAINTENANCE PROCEDURES ARE SUITABLE FOR SAFE START-UP.

               COMPLIANCE AUDITS:  COMPLIANCE AUDITS ARE CONDUCTED ON A REGULAR BASIS, AT 
            LEAST EVERY THREE YEARS.  THE MOST RECENT WAS ON 12-21-01.  CORRECTIVE ACTIONS 
            ARE  UNDERTAKEN IN A SAFE AND PROMPT MANNER.

               INCIDENT INVESTIGATION:  KIRSCHENMAN PACKING WILL PROMPTLY INVESTIGATE
            INCIDENTS WHICH RESULTED IN OR REASONABLY COULD HAVE RESULTED IN A CATASROPHIC
            RELEASE OF A REGULATED SUBSTANCE, TO IDENTIFY THE SITUATION LEADING TO THE 
            ACCIDENT, AS WELL AS CORRECTIVE ACTIONS TO PREVENT A RECURRENCE. REPORTS
            ARE RETAINED FOR FIVE YEARS.

                EMPLOYEE PARTICIPATION:  KIRSCHENMAN  PACKING BELIEVES THAT PROCESS 
            SAFETY MANAGEMENT IS A TEAM EFFORT.  EMPLOYEES ARE ENCOURAGED TO EXPRESS
            VIEWS CONCERNING ACCIDENT PREVENTION ISSUES AND RECOMMENDED IMPROVE

MENTS.
            EMPLOYEES HAVE ACCESS TO ALL SAFETY AND HAZARDOUS MATERIALS INFORMATION
            INCLUDING PROCESS HAZARD ANALYSIS INFORMATION.

                 CONTRACTORS:  WHEN KIRSCHENMAN PACKING EMPLOYS CONTRACTORS TO PERFORM
            SPECIALIZED MAINTENANCE AND CONSTRUCTION ACTIVITIES, ONLY CONTRACTORS OF
            HIGH REPUTE WITHIN THE INDUSTRY, LISCENCED BY THE STATE OF CALIFORNIA, OR  
            OTHER GOVERNMENTAL AGENCIES ARE EMPLOYED.

                  CONTRACTORS ARE INFORMED OF POTENTIAL PROCESS HAZARDS, AS WELL AS 
            EMERGENCY PROCEDURES IN CASE OF THE ACCIDENTAL RELEASE OF A REGULATED
            SUBSTANCE.  CONTRACTORS ARE FURTHER ASKED TO CERTIFY THAT THEIR
            EMPLOYEES ARE COMPETENT AND KNOWLEDGEABLE IN THE PROCESS INVOLVED
            AND THAT THEIR EMPLOYEES WILL PROMPTLY INFORM KIRSCHENMAN PACKING OF
            HAZARDS OR POTENTIAL HAZARDS IDENTIFIED IN THE COURSE OF PERFORMING
            THEIR  WORK.


          
            5.    FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY:

                    THERE HAVE BEEN NO ACCIDENTAL RELEASES OF HAZARDOUS CHEMICALS IN 
             THE LAST FIVE YEARS.



             6.   EMERGENCY RESPONSE PLAN:  

                   KIRSCHENMAN PACKING HAS A WRITTEN EMERGENCY RESPONSE PLAN TO
              DEAL WITH ACCIDENTAL RELEASES OF HAZARDOUS MATERIALS.  THE PLAN
              INCLUDES FIRST AID AND MEDICAL TREATMENT TO DEAL WITH EXPOSURES
              TO  HAZARDOUS SUBSTANCES IN ACCORDANCE WITH  MATERIAL SAFETY
              DATA SHEET RECOMMENDATIONS, EVACUATION NOTIFICATION OF EMERGENCY
              RESPONDERS, AND PUBLIC RECEPTORS.

                   THIS PLAN WILL BE UPDATED TO REFLECT CHANGES IN OPERATIONS WHICH
              MIGHT REQUIRE MODIFICATIONS.


               7.   PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY:

                      SEVERAL DEVELOPMENTS  AND FINDINGS  HAVE RESULTED  FROM THE 
               IMPLEMENTATION OF THE VARIOUS ELEMENTS OF OUR ACCIDENTAL RELEASE

PREVENTION PROGRAM.  HAZARDOUS MATERIALS TRAINING, SAFETY MEETINGS AND 
               SAFETY INSPECTIONS ARE SOME OF THE MAJOR STEPS WE WILL TAKE TO
               IMPROVE SAFETY AT OUR FACILITY.  THESE CHANGES WILL BE IN PLACE BY
               12-31-01.
